EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

OVERVIEW OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
OSRAM SYLVANIA PRODUCTS INC. operates a manufacturing facility at 1128 Roosevelt Avenue, York PA 17404.  The facility has five product lines:  Metal Base - a metal base stamping and glassing operation for incandescent and fluorescent bases; CPI - high-speed precision metal stamping; DPC - oxidation process for CRT components; GTMS - glass to metal seal operation for fuel sensors; and ACS - an audio cable and component assembly department.  The facility has a registered Environmental Management System conforming to ISO 14001.  The facility also has a Safety Management System based on BS-18001.

Anhydrous ammonia is the only RMP regulated substance handled.  Anhydrous ammonia is ?cracked? through a dissociation process into ?D/A? or dissociated ammonia, which is basically a gas made up of 75% hydrogen and 25% nitrogen.  The D/A gas is used as a furnace atmosphere in the DPC and GTMS areas for heat treating metal components.  The anhydrous ammonia system includes a bulk tank, process piping, various safety and monitoring systems and two electric fired dissociators.  The system is typically unmanned, but is monitored by plant security personnel.  The system undergoes a rigorous safety inspection each month.  Maintenance employees are on staff to respond to any alarms and to maintain the system.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
OSRAM SYLVANIA?s Risk Management Plan provides a unified approach to the prevention of accidental releases of chemicals through the integration of engineering controls, administrative controls and administrative procedures.  All applicable procedures from the USEPA Prevention Program are adhered to in the Risk Management Plan.  The OSRAM SYLVANIA emergency response plans include the preparation of response plans designed specifically for the OSRAM SYLVANIA facility located in York, PA and to the emergency response services that are available in the co

mmunity, as detailed in the OSRAM SYLVANIA Off-Site plan submitted and approved by the York County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  The Emergency Response Plan is also in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program Requirements.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The general accidental release and chemical specific prevention program is as follows:
    Safety Training for employees who inspect and maintain the system.
    Effective, detailed procedures for maintenance, operation and troubleshooting of the system.
    Preventive maintenance programs to maintain good mechanical integrity of the system.
    The Management of Change Program identifies potential concerns prior to system changes occurring.
    Detailed inspection program identifies potential concerns before they become a problem.  
    The Inspection program includes low level leak detection activities.
    The compliance audit program meets the criteria of OSHA?s Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.
    Chemical sensors at the bulk tank and in the dissociator room are set to low levels to provide early warning in the event of a release.
    Chemical specific prevention steps for anhydrous ammonia include: Level A, Level B and Level C Personal Protective Equipment to be used for emergency response and maintenance activities; training of emergency responders and maintenance employees on the toxic and physical properties of anhydrous ammonia, as well as all related procedures and work instructions; the chemical sensing system and other safety systems; training of plant security personnel (who conduct daily monitoring activities) to the OSHA First Responder (8-hour) level.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT RELEASE HISTORY
There have been no reportable accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
OSRAM SYLVANIA has a comprehensive emergency response plan that includes chemical specific response procedures as well as

an Off-Site Plan that has been approved by the York County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  OSRAM SYLVANIA has emergency responders trained at the 24-hour technician level (OSHA HAZWOPER Standard).  These individuals are trained to respond to the release of anhydrous ammonia and response plans for handling on-site releases of anhydrous ammonia exist.  The emergency response team is well equipped with:
    Chemical sensing equipment
    Personal protective equipment
    Radio communication equipment
    Offensive and defensive strategy tools and equipment
    Pre-determined response checklists for Incident Command, Safety/Science Officer and Decon Officer
    Decon and Emergency Decon equipment
    Medical supplies
    All equipment is staged on fully portable carts to enhance response capabilities
    Chemical detection sensors at the anhydrous ammonia process include a low level alarm, which maintenance or HazMat members will respond to and a high level alarm, which will sound internally over the fire/chemical evacuation system.  All plant employees are trained to respond to a high level anhydrous ammonia release by conducting shelter-in-place activities.
    Use of the Incident Command system for all OSRAM SYLVANIA emergency response teams (fire, chemical and other situations) use the Incident Command System as a reporting response structure.  Specific response plans include shelter-in-place, evacuation and response for chemical incidents, including the release of anhydrous ammonia.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS, MECHANICAL INTEGRITY AND COMPLIANCE AUDITS AND PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The initial Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in 1997 using the FMECA (Failure Mode and Effect Criticality Analysis) method, which met the criteria of 29 CFR 1910.119.  All recommendations from the 1997 PHA have been completed.

In December of 2003, a second Process Hazard Analysis was conducted using the ?What If?? Method, which also met the criteria of 29 CFR 1910.119.  A total of 67 recomme

ndations were made by the Process Hazard Analysis Team.  As of 5/24/04, only two recommendations are still open.  One involves clarification of information from the dissociator manufacturer concerning the retorts (which is a production planning, preventative maintenance item) and the replacement of the roto-gauge on the ammonia bulk tank with the same device, which is a replacement in kind.  Both of these recommendations will be completed by 8/1/2004.

Mechanical Integrity Audits are conducted every three years, with the last audit being completed on 9/15/2003.  The most current version of ANSI K-61 is used as the basis for the audit.  Monthly inspections verify the on-going mechanical integrity of the system.  Results of the monthly inspections are reviewed and corrective or preventive actions are taken, based on the results.  A formal corrective and preventive action system is operated and maintained with the facility?s Environmental And Safety Management Systems.  Preventive Maintenance plans are also fully documented and implemented to maintain the integrity of the anhydrous ammonia system.

Thorough Process Safety Management Compliance Audits are conducted every three years, with the latest completed on 9/16/2003.  The audit format includes a thorough review of the system and all elements, as well as all systems or procedures that are covered or referred to in 29 CFR 1910.119.  This included the review of 34 programs or documents which have an impact where the failure to properly follow procedures could result in the release of anhydrous ammonia.  Examples of the programs included Process Safety Management, Emergency Response Plans, Troubleshooting guides, Safe Work Practices, Operating Instructions, Calibration and Testing of Monitoring systems, Hot Work and Line Break Permit Programs, Incident Investigations, Outside Contractor Policy, and training documents.  A total of 20 recommendations were made as a result of the compliance audit and all have been comple
ted as of 5/24/2004, with the exception of the roto-gauge replacement that was also identified in the PHA.  The replacement will be completed by 8/1/2004.
